''{{lang|egy|db\ua723}}''{{sfn | Allen | 2014 |p=498}} || Reed float ||\n|}\n\n== Usage ==\n\nTriliteral signs could be used by themselves to indicate the consonant sequence they represent, or they could more often be written along with phonetic complements, that is, they could appear with [[Egyptian_uniliteral_signs|uniliteral signs]] that represent part of their value.{{sfn | Allen | 2014 | p=33}}{{sfn | Beylage | 2018 | p=26}} Some examples of triliterals with phonetic complementation appear in the table below.\n\n{|class=\"wikitable\" \n|+ Examples of phonetic complementation with
